oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Experimental studies to determine the nature of ecological interactions between invasive and native species are necessary for conserving and restoring native species in impacted habitats. Theory predicts that species boundaries along environmental gradients are determined by physical factors in stressful environments and by competitive ability in benign environments, but little is known about the mechanisms by which hydrophytes exclude halophytes and the life history stage at which these mechanisms are able to operate. The ongoing invasion of the South American<jats:italic>Spartina densiflora</jats:italic>in European marshes is causing concern about potential impacts to native plants along the marsh salinity gradient, offering an opportunity to evaluate the mechanisms by which native hydrophytes may limit, or even prevent, the expansion of invasive halophytes. Our study compared<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>seedling establishment with and without competition with<jats:italic>Phragmites australis</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>Typha domingensis</jats:italic>, two hydrophytes differing in clonal architecture. We hypothesized that seedlings of the stress tolerant<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>would be out-competed by stands of<jats:italic>P. australis</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>T. domingensis</jats:italic>. Growth, survivorship, biomass patterns and foliar nutrient content were recorded in a common garden experiment to determine the effect of mature<jats:italic>P. australis</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>T. domingensis</jats:italic>on the growth and colonization of<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>under fresh water conditions where invasion events are likely to occur. Mature<jats:italic>P. australis</jats:italic>stands prevented establishment of<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>seedlings and<jats:italic>T. domingensis</jats:italic>reduced<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>establishment by 38%. Seedlings grown with<jats:italic>P. australis</jats:italic>produced fewer than five short shoots and all plants died after ca. 2 yrs. Our results showed that direct competition, most likely for subterranean resources, was responsible for decreased growth rate and survivorship of<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>. The presence of healthy stands of<jats:italic>P. australis</jats:italic>, and to some extent<jats:italic>T. domingensis</jats:italic>, along river channels and in brackish marshes may prevent the invasion of<jats:italic>S. densiflora</jats:italic>by stopping the establishment of its seedlings.</jats:p>
